title: That Which I Should Have Done I Did Not Do (The Door)

thumbnail.alt_text: Shallow and tall painting tightly focused on a black paneled door, a wreath of dying flowers hanging on it and a hand reaching to the doorknob from left.

description: Replete with powerful imagery and bearing a long, philosophical title, That Which I Should Have Done I Did Not Do (The Door) is an evocative meditation on the choices and regrets in life. Ivan Albright considered The Door to be his most important picture, and he worked for ten years to achieve its mesmerizing effect. He spent weeks collecting props for the painting: a marred Victorian door found in a junkyard, a faded wax funeral wreath, and a tombstone for the doorsill. Once he arranged these objects, Albright completed an elaborate charcoal underdrawing that he then covered with the intricate and obsessively painted detail that characterizes most of his work. He would often finish no more than a quarter of a square inch a day. A wrinkled, aging woman’s hand rests on the carved doorway, a faded blue handkerchief clenched between the fingers. The poignant placement of the hand, near but not touching the doorknob, only underscores the sense of remorse and mourning implied by the painting. With its profound themes of mortality and the passage of time, The Door is a modern memento mori that encourages a consideration of the brevity of human existence.
inscriptions: Signed lower right: Ivan Le Lorraine Albright

Hyatt Mayor, "The Artists for Victory Exhibition," The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin (Dec. 1942): 142 (ill.), as That Which I Should Have Done, I Did Not Do. Edward Alden Jewell, "'Artists for Victory': Metropolitan Opens Tomorrow the Huge American Survey," The New York Times, Dec. 6, 1942, 259, as That Which I Should Have Done I Did Not Do. "Record Art Show Has $52,000 Prizes: Artists for Victory Display at Metropolitan Museum Totals 918 Exhibits," The New York Times, Dec. 7, 1942, 30 (ill.), as That Which I Should Have Done, I Did Not Do. "Metropolitan Opens Artists for Victory Exhibition," New York Herald Tribune, Dec. 8, 1942, as That Which I Should Have Done, I Did Not Do. Edward Alden Jewell, "Artists for Victory: Afterthoughts on the Huge Nation-Wide Survey at the Metropolitan Museum," The New York Times, Dec. 20, 1942, 150, as That Which I Should Have Done, I Did Not Do. Alfred M. Frankfurter, "The Artists for Victory Exhibition: The Paintings," Art News 41, 16 (Jan. 1-14, 1943): 9 (ill.), 11, as That Which I Should Have Done, I Did Not Do. Daniel Catton Rich, “Ivan Le Lorraine Albright: Our Own Jeremiah,” Magazine of Art 36, 2 (Feb. 1943), 49–51 (ill.). Margaret S. Marble [Margaret Sharp], The Lady Forgot (Harper, 1947), 208–209. Judith A. Barter et al., American Modernism at the Art Institute of Chicago, From World War I to 1955 (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2009), cat. 91. Sarah Kelly Oehler, ed., Ivan Albright Paintings at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2019), https://www.artic.edu/digitalalbright, cat. 13 (ill.).

provenance_text: Ivan Albright, from 1941 to 1955; partially exchanged for Heavy the Oar to Him Who Is Tired, Heavy the Coat, Heavy the Sea (then 1949.961, now 1959.12), Into the World There Came a Soul Called Ida (then 1947.519, now 1977.34), and Oh God, Herrings, Buoys, the Glittering Sea (then 1941.828, now 1977.32) and sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1955.
